Famine in India, China, Brazil, Northern Africa (and other countries). Famine in northern China killed 9–13 million people. 5.5 million died in the Great Famine of 1876–78 in India. 500,000 died in Brazil. British policies and drought were responsible for the deaths in India. The famine in China was a result of drought influenced by the El Niño-Southern Oscillation.
column4: India, China, Brazil, Northern Africa (and other countries).

column3: 1879 Famine in Ireland. Unlike previous famines, this famine mainly caused hunger and food shortages but little mortality.

Ethiopian Great famine. About one-third of the population died. Conditions worsen with cholera outbreaks (1889–92), a typhus epidemic, and a major smallpox epidemic (1889–90).
Russian famine of 1891–92. Beginning along the Volga River and spreading to the Urals and the Black Sea.

Famine in northern China leading in part to the Boxer Rebellion
Indian famine of 1896–97 and Indian famine of 1899–1900 due to drought and British policies.

Famine in Morocco between 1940–48, because of refueling system installed by France.

Leningrad famine caused by a 900-day blockade by German troops. About one million Leningrad residents starved, froze, or were bombed to death in the winter of 1941–42, when supply routes to the city were cut off and temperatures dropped to ?40 °C (?40 °F).

The Great Chinese Famine, which is widely regarded as the greatest famine in human history. Some researchers also include the year 1958 or 1962.
